Advance for PMs Thursday, 5/13/76. WITH UPI DISPATCH, "THOMAS," BY FRED T. FERGUSON. [?]867404-5/13/76-NEW YORK: It has taken Lowell Thomas 51 years of broadcasting, many more in public speaking, scores of films and 52 books to tell the things he has seen and done from Allenby at Jerusalem and Lawrence in Arabia to Shangrila [sic] and Timbucktu [sic] with thousands of points in between. Thomas is shown during interview with UPI 5/7. In background is a painting of (T. E.) Lawrence in Arabia. UPI (THOMAS) hgr/jl [5 copies]

Note: Advance for PMs Thursday, 5/13/76. WITH UPI DISPATCH, "THOMAS," BY FRED T. FERGUSON. [?]867404-5/13/76-NEW YORK: It has taken Lowell Thomas 51 years of broadcasting, many more in public speaking, scores of films and 52 books to tell the things he has seen and done from Allenby at Jerusalem and Lawrence in Arabia to Shangrila [sic] and Timbucktu [sic] with thousands of points in between. Thomas is shown during interview with UPI 5/7. In background is a painting of (T. E.) Lawrence in Arabia. UPI (THOMAS) hgr/jl

Note: Beaver Valley Ranch; Dear Mrs. Nicks, Enclosed are twelve snapshots of the interior of the Boyhood Home of Lowell Thomas. A brief description is written on the back of each picture. I hope these will be helpful in assembling material for the tape. Yours Truly, Ruth Harclerode (Mrs. F. R. Harclerode)

Furnas, Director of the Curtiss-Wright Research Laboratory. Lowell Thomas: Broadcasting

Father and son act, Lowell Thomas, Jr., (left) reports to his famous father on Thomas Senior's nightly radio newscast after returning from an extended trip in Persia. Lowell Junior is following in the exact footsteps of his father, who is radio's oldest newscaster, having started in 1930. The younger Thomas is planning a lecture series based on his voyaging. 12/13/48

Note: Father and son act, Lowell Thomas, Jr., (left) reports to his famous father on Thomas Senior's nightly radio newscast after returning from an extended trip in Persia. Lowell Junior is following in the exact footsteps of his father, who is radio's oldest newscaster, having started in 1930. The younger Thomas is planning a lecture series based on his voyaging. 12/13/48

Lowell Thomas: Broadcasting [final broadcast]

NXP1868419-5/15/76-New York: Lowell Thomas signs off for the last time 5/15 as the longest running radio network program goes off the air after 46 years. The familiar "So long until tomorrow" became "So long for now" as Thomas completed his last five-minute news broadcast. The end of his broadcasting career does not mean retirement for Thomas, who is 84. He has written 54 books and has several more planned. UPI

Verso: NXP1868419-5/15/76-New York: Lowell Thomas signs off for the last time 5/15 as the longest running radio network program goes off the air after 46 years. The familiar "So long until tomorrow" became "So long for now" as Thomas completed his last five-minute news broadcast. The end of his broadcasting career does not mean retirement for Thomas, who is 84. He has written 54 books and has several more planned. UPI

Lowell Thomas: Cripple Creek/Victor, Colorado
Note: Additional Fredstone - Cripple Creek pix. (Did you want to send one to the Cripple Creek paper?)
Caption: Leo Ruschenberg's Cabin; Cripple Creek /93/ Fred Stone/ Bert Ragan / Youngdale[?]/ Leo Welch

Verso: Dear Lowell Thomas, This is a picture of our cabin in Cripple Creek. You once told me you were born there in 1893. This cabin is back of our theatre. I am on the extreme left of the picture. Each of the others were musicians and each had a job to do. They called me "Jimmy Gets" ( get-the- wood- and- water- boy ). Also actor - I hoped! Merry Christmas to you. [signed] Fred Stone
Caption: Leo Ruschenberg's Cabin; Cripple Creek /93/ Fred Stone/ Bert Ragan / Youngdale[?]/ Leo Welch

Note: Victor High School track team 1907 or 1908 Standing, left to right: 1. Coach Boughton 2. ?? 3. Leslie Schoen 4. Joe Brill 5. Walter Schoen 6. Homer Huffaker Seated: 1. Lowell Thomas 2. Harry Black 3. Donald Kennedy 4. ?Vincent? Reclining: Clyde Black The Lowell Thomas Museum, Victor Colorado Dear Friends: Among some old pictures I found this one of the Victor High School track team, taken in 1907 or 1908, and I thought you might like to have it for your collection. Sincerely yours, Homer Huffaker Chino Valley, Arizona November 27, 1963

Professor Taylor, Principle of Victor High School

Note: Professor Taylor, Principal of the Victor High School, friend of my father, and a top flight educator. He's one of two of my teachers who actually gave me a licking. The other was a woman, an amazon who was my teacher in the 8th grade. She also was a great person and I'm sorry I've forgotten her name. I believe she later became a doctor in Fort Collins, Colorado. Professor Taylor was quite right in giving me that licking?

Lowell Thomas: Cripple Creek/Victor, Colorado [Lowell Thomas and Governor Ralph Carr visit]

Lowell Thomas, center, points out object to his son, left, while former Governor of Colorado, Ralph Carr, looks on. The three are standing in front of the old Victor Record Bldg. Thomas, son of the Miller's family physician, is a former Record newsboy. Carr served as a reporter on the Record before completing his law studies.

Note: Lowell Thomas, center, points out object to his son, left, while former Governor of Colorado, Ralph Carr, looks on. The three are standing in front of the old Victor Record Bldg. Thomas, son of the Miller's family physician, is a former Record newsboy. Carr served as a reporter on the Record before completing his law studies.

Lowell Thomas: Cripple Creek/Victor, Colorado [Carlton Mill opening]

A donkey used by Elza Fay (left) in his role as a gold prospector provided a picturesque prop Monday for photographers snapping pictures after the parade in Cripple Creek which raised the curtain on activities in connection with the Carlton Mill. Mrs. A. E. Carlton, widow of one of the men after whom the mill is named, is also shown in the picture with Lowell Thomas, who dedicated the mill

Note: [newspaper clipping] A donkey used by Elza Fay (left) in his role as a gold prospector provided a picturesque prop Monday for photographers snapping pictures after the parade in Cripple Creek which raised the curtain on activities in connection with the Carlton mill. Mrs. A. E. Carlton, widow of one of the men after whom the mill is named, is also shown in the picture with Lowell Thomas, who dedicated the mill

Lowell Thomas: Cripple Creek/Victor, Colorado [Carlton Mill opening]

There was lots to talk about when two "old-timers" of the Cripple Creek-Victor district, John White, left, and Dr. H. G. Thomas, right, got together Monday in Cripple Creek. Listening to the reminiscing by the pair at Cripple Creek Elks club building is Mrs. Pherbia Thornburg, daughter of Dr. Thomas and sister of Radio News Commentator Lowell Thomas

Note: There was lots to talk about when two "old-timers" of the Cripple Creek-Victor district, John White, left, and Dr. H. G. Thomas, right, got together Monday in Cripple Creek. Listening to the reminiscing by the pair at Cripple Creek Elks club building is Mrs. Pherbia Thornburg, daughter of Dr. Thomas and sister of Radio News Commentator Lowell Thomas

Shown addressing the nearly 3,000 persons who attended dedication ceremonies of the Carlton mill Monday in Cripple Creek-Victor gold district is Merrill E. Shoup, president of the Golden Cycle corporation, builder of the mill and owner of mines in the district. In the front row immediately behind Shoup are, left to right, Mrs. Ethel Carlton, a director of the corporation and widow of A. E. Carlton, mining man; Lowell Thomas, CBS news commentator; Max Bowen, Golden Cycle vice-president; Mrs. A. C. Magruder, sister of the late A. E. and L. G. Carlton, and Dr. H. G. Thomas, early day Victor physician and father of Lowell Thomas

Note: Shown addressing the nearly 3,000 persons who attended dedication ceremonies of the Carlton mill Monday in Cripple Creek-Victor gold district is Merrill E. Shoup, president of the Golden Cycle corporation, builder of the mill and owner of mines in the district. In the front row immediately behind Shoup are, left to right, Mrs. Ethel Carlton, a director of the corporation and widow of A. E. Carlton, mining man; Lowell Thomas, CBS news commentator; Max Bowen, Golden Cycle vice-president; Mrs. A. C. Magruder, sister of the late A. E. and L. G. Carlton, and Dr. H. G. Thomas, early day Victor physician and father of Lowell Thomas

Lowell Thomas, the district's favorite son, on Monday, March [?], pushed a very important button. The button started the wheels turning in the huge Carlton gold reduction mill just completed by the Golden Cycle corporation

This is Mr. Segard one of my best friends. He's a graduate of Columbia and the brightest boy I ever met. He takes a very active part in school and also leads the choir at the Christian church. His home is in San Francisco. He was captain of a submarine in the U.S. Navy for two yrs. and is only 25 yrs old

Lowell Thomas: Honors

Photograph by Newspictures, Inc. Note: The Splendid American Award presented annually by the Thomas A. Dooley Foundation, the Splendid American Award honors those Americans whose personal accomplishments have well reflected the meaning and purpose of the United States to the world community. The award was established in 1964 by the authors of "The Ugly American," William J. Lederer and the late Eugene Burdick. Mr. Burdick was President of the Dooley Foundation from 1961 until his death in 1965. Mr. Lederer each year presents the awards.

Note: Photograph by Newspictures, Inc. Note: The Splendid American Award presented annually by the Thomas A. Dooley Foundation, the Splendid American Award honors those Americans whose personal accomplishments have well reflected the meaning and purpose of the United States to the world community. The award was established in 1964 by the authors of "The Ugly American," William J. Lederer and the late Eugene Burdick. Mr. Burdick was President of the Dooley Foundation from 1961 until his death in 1965. Mr. Lederer each year presents the awards.

Letter to L.T. from Paul F. Hartz: Dear Lowell, Just revieved a pleasant reminder of the nice evening we had at the Explorer's Club in November of last year in the form of a new photographs.; If by chance you keep a scrapbook, I thought you might be interested in having the attached photograph.; Warmest regards, Sincerely, [signed] Paul F Hartz

Note: Letter to L.T. from Paul F. Hartz: Dear Lowell, Just revieved a pleasant reminder of the nice evening we had at the Explorer's Club in November of last year in the form of a new photographs.; If by chance you keep a scrapbook, I thought you might be interested in having the attached photograph.; Warmest regards, Sincerely, [signed] Paul F Hartz
[Governor's Award, 1976, Ohio]

Note: Letter to L.T. from Paul J. Sherlock: Dear Mr. Thomas: We regret the delay in sending you pictures of the Governor's Awards presentation ceremonies. Our one staff photographs has been so swamped with assignments that he couldn't get around to processing the film until now.; At any rate, we hope that the enclosed pictures will bring back pleasant memories of the evening's activities when Ohio's highest token of appreciation, the Governor's Award, was presented to you in recognition of your achievements benefiting mankind and for bringing honor and prestige to the Buckeye State.; Sincerely, [signed] Pauk J. Sherlock, Governor's Awards Coordinator
7/7/76 Governor's Island Presentation of Scrolls to new members. From left to right: George Sanborn, George Gettemuller, Clarence O'Connor, Elwyn Chesley, Joseph Conlin [The Circumnavigators Club]
